awd_titl_txt: CAREER: On the Engineering of Light Metals for Enhanced Dynamic Properties and Fatigue Performance
awd_abstract_narration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The goal of this CAREER award to Worcester Polytechnic Institute is to build and integrate fundamental knowledge of materials science and fracture mechanics to aid in the optimization of existing light metal alloys and the development of new and lighter alloys designed for improved fatigue and fatigue crack growth resistance in structural applications.  This research will also lead to the creation of original experimental, analytical, and computational tools and strategies for accurate fatigue life predictions and design of fatigue-critical and high-integrity structural components.  The proposed work will provide a fundamental understanding of the fatigue crack growth mechanisms at the micro-/nano-structural scale of light metals, as well as methods for improved design.  In addition to their contributions to the scientific community, the results of this work will also impact the industry -- both the materials and processing and design communities.  On a larger scale, complementary to the improvements in materials design and fatigue performance, these developments will contribute to important reductions in fuel consumption and carbon emissions.


NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Our nation's ambitious energy goals and reduced carbon pollution can only be achieved if the transition to renewable and clean energy will be complemented by effective venues to reduce vehicle weight.  Weight reductions will translate into reductions in fuel consumption, and consequently, reductions in the carbon footprint.  One way to reduce vehicle weight is to replace ferrous materials in structural components with well-engineered lighter metals.  In structural components, the dynamic properties and fatigue performance of the materials are critical as more than 90% of all mechanical failures are fatigue related.  Therefore, a transition to lighter metals in such applications needs to be based on a fundamental understanding and optimization of the fatigue behavior of the materials.  Another means to reduce weight is to use accurate life prediction tools to design structural components with a higher degree of confidence, which requires appropriate fatigue data generation, interpretation, and use.  This will allow applying sufficient yet not excessive safety factors, which will result in further weight and cost reductions.  The CAREER award to Worcester Polytechnic Institute will support both fronts by providing a mechanistic understanding of fatigue in light metals, as well as methods for improved design.  The ultimate goal of the work is to facilitate the design of better, lighter, and more reliable structural components for the transportation sector.  Through direct collaborations with the industry, the knowledge, data, and techniques emerging from this work will be effectively validated and implemented.  In the broader impact of this award, a wide spectrum of activities will be used to stimulate the interest and engagement in fundamental and applied science and materials science of a range of students from undergraduate and graduate to middle- and high-school to professionals.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this research is to build and integrate fundamental knowledge of materials science with fracture mechanics to aid in the development and optimization of light metal alloys for improved fatigue and fatigue crack growth (FCG) resistance in high-integrity applications.  This will facilitate the confident adoption and use of high-performance and reliable structural materials sought by the transportation sector, while contributing to reductions in fuel consumption and carbon emissions.  Major activities made possible by this grant included fundamental investigations of microstructure-scale FCG phenomena, development of analytical and computational predictive models, dissemination of fatigue design methods and tools to industrial communities of interest for implementation, and various educational opportunities.

Mechanisms of FCG are dependent on the characteristic microstructure of an alloy and associated with the crack path selection relative to secondary phase particles and/or grain boundaries.  Several cast and wrought aluminum alloys were systematically investigated in various processing and loading conditions to fundamentally understand the role of microstructure and establish processing-structure-performance relationships.  This resulted in a library of well-pedigreed FCG data with supporting mechanical properties and fractographic data.  Complementary to the development of the database, this study also resolved an open question related to the mechanisms of interaction between an advancing fatigue crack and the eutectic silicon particles embedded in the aluminum matrix of the cast alloys.  For spherical silicon particles (modified morphology), it was observed that at low crack driving force (stress intensity) the crack preferentially debonds the particles from the matrix, and conversely fractures them at high driving force.  This change in mechanisms was clarified by transmission electron microscope (TEM) studies of samples prepared by focused ion beam (FIB) milling, extracted from within eutectic silicon colonies along the fracture surface at different stress intensities.  These studies revealed that low dislocation density and mobility at low driving force (low plastic strain amplitude) permit the elimination of dislocations at the matrix-particle interface, whereas at high driving force, dislocations form entanglements that prohibit movement and create a localized stress field that causes particle fracture.  For plate-like silicon particles (unmodified morphology), the tendency to debond or fracture particles is more dependent on the plate orientation with respect to the crack than stress intensity, which is attributed to geometric stress concentrations, however similar localized dislocation accumulations were observed for the two failure modes.  With this knowledge, the mechanisms at the nanoscale are directly related to the observed mesoscopic mechanisms of crack growth and translate the microstructural damage behavior across multiple length scales, assisting in the material-process optimization for FCG resistance.

Various design methodologies were created to bridge the gap between materials science and engineering design.  Load-microstructure-damage design maps were synthesized by combination of FCG data and fractographic studies to uniquely identify the microstructural mode of crack growth for a specified loading condition.  These maps support material/component design and optimization for FCG resistance, as well as provide guidance for scheduling component inspections and performing failure analysis.  Additionally, statistically based, microstructure-sensitive analytical models were developed to predict FCG data for untested materials.  This approach enables engineers to incorporate the inherently stochastic behavior in the design process, and facilitates rapid development and selection of materials for structural integrity.

Computational studies using the extended finite element method (XFEM) were conducted to predict and simulate microstructure-scale crack path selection and growth rates.  The simulations incorporated several of the observed fracture mechanisms, including particle debonding (cohesive element formulation), particle fracture, and elasto-plastic fracture mechanics.  The non-linear constitutive behavior required implementation of the Newton-Raphson method to obtain iterative convergence of the system of equations, and supporting algorithms leveraging directed acyclic graph theory and Cholesky matrix factorization were used to develop a robust and efficient parallelized solution routine.  A graphical user interface was developed to enable access by diverse audiences to the computational software.

Complementary to the scholastic and technical accomplishments of this research, the award contributed to the development and advancement of human and societal resources.  Two researchers were mentored in their doctoral/post-doctoral studies and professional activities, several courses were enhanced, and various educational outreach programs were created to increase awareness of STEM fields, with particular emphasis on young girls grades 5-7 and high school students and teachers.  These educational programs were developed and delivered in collaboration with ASM International - New England Chapters, WPI's office of summer programs, NASA's TouchTomorrow science festival, TMS symposia, and the iMdc industry-government-university consortium at Worcester Polytechnic Institute (WPI).


Last Modified: 05/02/2022
Modified by: Diana A Lados

    Anthony G. Spangenberger and Diana A. Lados
    Copyrighted

    Cast A356 Aluminum Fatigue Crack Growth Data

    Anthony G. Spangenberger and Diana A. Lados
    Copyrighted
    Diana A Lados
    Electron Backscatter Diffraction for a Crack Interacting with an Intergranular Silicon Particle Colony

    Anthony G. Spangenberger and Diana A. Lados

    Load-Microstructure-Damage Design Map for Cast A356 Aluminum
  • A computational model of stress redistribution by a fatigue crack in the vicinity of a fractured eutectic silicon particle in a cast aluminum alloy.
    Anthony G. Spangenberger and Diana A. Lados
    Copyrighted

    Simulated Stress Distribution in a Crack-Particle Interaction
  • A summer outreach program for young women designed to introduce them to materials science using exciting hands-on activities.
    Anthony G. Spangenberger and Diana A. Lados
    Copyrighted
    Diana A Lados
    A Lab Activity for the Young Women in Materials Science Program
por.por_txt_cntn:
The goal of this research is to build and integrate fundamental knowledge of materials science with fracture mechanics to aid in the development and optimization of light metal alloys for improved fatigue and fatigue crack growth (FCG) resistance in high-integrity applications.  This will facilitate the confident adoption and use of high-performance and reliable structural materials sought by the transportation sector, while contributing to reductions in fuel consumption and carbon emissions.  Major activities made possible by this grant included fundamental investigations of microstructure-scale FCG phenomena, development of analytical and computational predictive models, dissemination of fatigue design methods and tools to industrial communities of interest for implementation, and various educational opportunities.

Mechanisms of FCG are dependent on the characteristic microstructure of an alloy and associated with the crack path selection relative to secondary phase particles and/or grain boundaries. Various design methodologies were created to bridge the gap between materials science and engineering design. A graphical user interface was developed to enable access by diverse audiences to the computational software.

Complementary to the scholastic and technical accomplishments of this research, the award contributed to the development and advancement of human and societal resources.  Two researchers were mentored in their doctoral/post-doctoral studies and professional activities, several courses were enhanced, and various educational outreach programs were created to increase awareness of STEM fields, with particular emphasis on young girls grades 5-7 and high school students and teachers.  These educational programs were developed and delivered in collaboration with ASM International - New England Chapters, WPI's office of summer programs, NASA's TouchTomorrow science festival, TMS symposia, and the iMdc industry-government-university consortium at Worcester Polytechnic Institute (WPI).
